header.title: The Scroll of Set: December 1986 - The Word of Remanifestation and Setian Progress
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Magical Philosophy

central_thesis: The December 1986 issue of The Scroll of Set announces the recognition of James Lewis V° as Magus and introduces his Word of the Æon, 'Remanifestation,' defining it as a logical, progressive step beyond 'Xeper' to address continued existence beyond the biological body and the outward manifestation of absorbed magical power. This new Word, alongside discussions of Setian philosophical and practical applications like the 'aUI' language, underscores the Temple's ongoing evolution in defining and advancing individual magical development and self-creation.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] Meet the New Magus - by Constance L. Moffatt IV°
structure_content.summary: This article introduces James Lewis V° upon his formal Recognition as Magus, detailing his biography, magical affiliations (Church of Satan, Temple of Set degrees), and his extensive leadership roles within the Temple of Set, including Chairman of the Council of Nine. His Word, 'Remanifestation,' is presented, with an initial comparison to 'Doctor Who's regeneration as a magical concept.

structure_content.chapter_title: [2] A New Magus, A New Word Within the Æon - by James Lewis V°
structure_content.summary: James Lewis V° personally expounds upon 'Remanifestation' as his Word, explaining its philosophical basis. It addresses humanity's questing nature and the desire to avoid 'personal annihilation' beyond the biological body, linking it to the 'infinity symbol'. The Word is also presented as the necessary outward manifestation ('do something and go somewhere') of power absorbed from Black Magic, positioning it as a continuation and development of the prior Word, 'Xeper,' for advanced Setian Initiates.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Degree Recognitions at Set-VII - by Constance L. Moffatt IV°
structure_content.summary: Announces the official Recognition of two new Masters of the Temple IV°, Constance M.L. Moffatt and Dr. Stephen E. Flowers, by Dr. Michael A. Aquino VI° at the Set-VII Conclave, with confirmation by the Council of Nine. Brief biographies for both are provided, highlighting their contributions and leadership roles within the Temple and associated Orders.

Magister Robert H. and Magistra Constance M.L. Moffatt announce the official retirement of the Set Amentet Pylon, which they co-founded eight years prior, noting its success and active membership in Los Angeles, San Diego, and Santa Barbara.

structure_content.chapter_title: [5] Setian Thoughts on a First Conclave - by Ruth E. Smith I°
structure_content.summary: A personal reflection by a new Setian on her first conclave experience (Set-VII), describing feelings of belonging, renewed purpose, and the unexpected connection with other members. The author also notes increased pleasure in martial arts (Aikijujutsu) as a direct result, linking it to the exercise of will.

structure_content.chapter_title: [6] The Order of the Scarab Publishes Statement
structure_content.summary: States that Co-Grand Masters Robert and Constance Moffatt published the opening statement of the Order of the Scarab as Crystal Tablet pages, included with the Scroll. Scarab Wings, formerly the Set Amentet Pylon newsletter, will continue as an Order of the Scarab publication, available to all degrees of Setians, with an immediate enrollment and future Temple-wide mailing planned.

structure_content.chapter_title: [7] Book Review: The Greater Trumps by Charles Williams - reviewed by Julie Stout II°
structure_content.summary: A review of Charles Williams' novel, 'The Greater Trumps,' which uses a pack of Tarot cards as a central narrative device. The reviewer analyzes the characters as embodying different Tarot archetypes (Fool, Lovers, Emperor, Magus, Hierophant), suggesting it as an entertaining introduction to Tarot concepts.

structure_content.chapter_title: [8] Let's Learn Martian - by George C. Smith I°
structure_content.summary: Introduces 'aUI,' or 'the language of space,' developed by Dr. John W. Weilgart, and its potential for 'human transformation' by shaping perception and cognition, akin to the 'Whorfian Hypothesis.' The article details nine specific benefits for Setians, including confidentiality, clarity, magical language, perceptual restructuring, telepathy, and an enhanced path to 'Xeper'.

structure_content.chapter_title: [9] From the Chairman, Council of Nine - by James Lewis V°
structure_content.summary: James Lewis V°, in his capacity as Chairman of the Council of Nine, reflects on the past year, the success of the Orders and new Pylons, and the significance of the recent IV° and V° Recognitions as manifestations of 'dedication to work without a 'lust for results'.' He expresses satisfaction with the Temple's magical efficiency and his role in guiding it, emphasizing the importance of the new Word, 'Remanifestation'.

A collection of anecdotal and humorous snippets of conversations and complaints overheard during the Set-VII Conclave, offering a lighthearted glimpse into the social dynamics and practicalities of the event.

structure_content.chapter_title: [11] Background on the Grail - by Nancy Flowers III°
structure_content.summary: Explores the term 'lapis elixir' from Wolfram von Eschenbach's Parzival, linking it to the philosopher's stone in alchemy and describing it as representing the 'light-dark unity of divine opposites.' The Grail is described as a stone through which the phoenix rejuvenates, illustrating themes of dual nature and immortality.

structure_content.chapter_title: [12] Book Review: My Scrapbook Memories of Dark Shadows - by Michael A. Aquino VI°
structure_content.summary: A detailed review of the TV show 'Dark Shadows' and Kathryn Leigh Scott's book. Dr. Aquino analyzes its cultural impact and occult relevance, particularly its exploration of Black Magic, reincarnation, time-travel, and parallel universes within a gothic soap-opera format, praising its inventiveness despite some narrative complexities.

structure_content.chapter_title: [13] Editorial - by Constance L. Moffatt IV°
structure_content.summary: The editor reflects on the successful Set-VII Conclave in New Orleans, thanking organizers and highlighting the positive experiences, including the workings of various Orders. She expresses excitement about the new Magus and the Word 'Remanifestation,' encouraging Setians to engage with it.

A poem describing a journey from a 'peopled park' to the 'strand' and into the 'Sea', symbolizing a transition from societal constraints to a deeper, more profound state of being, where the self is 'wrenched apart' and 'absorbed the all and became myself and more'.

A personal account of discovering achromatic color perception and its implications for subjective reality and the 'malleability' of time perception. The author theorizes that by 'interpreting' colors differently, one can challenge fixed perceptions, suggesting that this principle could extend to 'wavelengths of time' for magical influence, potentially prolonging life or creating unique realities, implying endless possibilities for altered perception.

structure_content.chapter_title: [16] Setian Filmography - edited by John Gyori II°
structure_content.summary: An annotated list of films deemed relevant to Setian themes, contributed by various individuals. Each entry provides production details, a brief synopsis, and commentary on its occult or philosophical significance from a Setian perspective, covering topics like revenge, invocation, unconventional Satanism, magic, immortality, consciousness, and archetypes.

key_concepts.definition: The highest degree within the Temple of Set, characterized as an 'initiate charged with the duty of communicating a new truth to mankind.' A Magus 'utters' a 'Word of the Æon,' a central magical concept that defines and guides Setian development for an era. James Lewis is the new Magus V°.

The new Word of the Æon introduced by Magus James Lewis V°. It addresses man's intrinsic 'questing nature' and the desire to avoid 'personal annihilation' beyond the biological body, indicating a continued existence. Magically, it represents the imperative for power absorbed from 'Black Magic' experiences to 'do something and go somewhere,' manifesting outwardly from the self into its environs. It is presented as a 'logical, progressive step' beyond 'Xeper'.

The previous 'Word of the Æon,' defined as 'coming into being.' Setians have worked with this concept, accumulating power and knowledge, leading to the necessity of 'Remanifestation' for further development.

A constructed language (by Dr. John W. Weilgart) proposed as a 'Martian' tongue. It is described as forcing the speaker to 'say exactly what he means,' reflecting 'basic categories of human thought and expression.' For Setians, it offers benefits like enhanced confidentiality, clarity of communication, perceptual restructuring ('reconstruction of your experience of reality'), potential telepathy, and a means to achieve 'Xeper via Whorfian Hypothesis' leading to an 'identity shift of superhuman proportions'.

Presented not as specific rituals but as a process involving the 'difficult art' of absorbing experiences. The power gained from this absorption 'must do something and go somewhere,' manifesting outwardly, which is intrinsically linked to the concept of 'Remanifestation'.

A central, epoch-defining magical concept 'uttered' by a Magus V°. It serves as a new truth to mankind, guiding the magical development and philosophy of the Temple of Set for a period, influencing how Initiates identify with and exert their will to establish this truth.

A benefit of learning aUI, where the language causes 'a reconstruction of your experience of reality.' An example given is the verb 'to see' (iOv), which literally translates to 'the action of feeling light,' implying a direct, tactile relationship with perception, and fostering the concept of psychokinesis (PK).

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined or implied in this document centers on the individual Initiate's pursuit of self-creation and continued existence, driven by the 'Word of the Æon.' This involves deeply understanding and applying 'Remanifestation' as a process of outward manifestation of internally absorbed power from 'Black Magic' experiences. The system is highly intellectual and philosophical, requiring continuous self-definition and the rejection of external dogma. It emphasizes the active development of the 'active self' to influence one's environs and prepare for a future beyond the biological body. Integral to this is the potential restructuring of perception and communication through specialized tools like the 'aUI' language.
tools: The philosophical understanding of the 'Word of the Æon' (Remanifestation and Xeper)
Black Magic (as a process of absorbing and manifesting power)
aUI: The Language of Space (for enhanced communication, perceptual restructuring, and magical application)
Individual will and intellect for self-creation and reality shaping.
rituals: O.T. working (Order of the Trapezoid ritual)
The act of 'Uttering a Word' as a Magus V°
Simple, highly symbolic workings such as speaking a curse by single candle light or gazing into a mirror (as seen in Dark Shadows).

relevant_quotes.text: 'Remanifestation enters the picture because man is by nature a questing creature and cannot abide the thought that his explorations might one day come to an end through the failure of the biological body. His awareness of the potential inherent in his accentuated self seeks to know how he can avoid personal annihilation.'
'The Magus, according to Aleister Crowley, is the “initiate charged with the duty of communicating a new truth to mankind”.'

'Remanifestation presently is easy to understand as a logical, progressive step, and I intend to see it remain clear and free of unnecessary trappings. There are indeed many deep and not-Understood aspects of it which for now reside only within the wisdom of its Magus. They will be expounded in time and will be lucid and intelligible. Remanifestation is a Word prepared to show itself to all and stand or fall on its own merits.'

'If I were to persist in putting forth my own perspective, you might argue that color is more than pigment. It is a measurable wavelength. It is part of the electromagnetic spectrum with a category all unto itself called “visible light". I will concede these points, but only so I might tell you that "time" too is measured in wavelengths.'

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for understanding the internal esoteric development and organizational structure of the Temple of Set in the mid-1980s. It details a significant event—the recognition of a new Magus and the introduction of a new 'Word of the Æon'—which represents a philosophical and practical advancement beyond previous Setian tenets. The articles provide primary source material on the evolution of Setian magical philosophy, particularly the interplay between 'Xeper' and 'Remanifestation,' and explore practical magical applications like the 'aUI' language and the philosophical implications of individual perception and Black Magic. It also offers insights into the community's cultural engagements through film analysis and personal reflections on conclaves, grounding the esoteric theory in lived experience.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates of the Temple of Set, particularly those at higher degrees (III° and above) who are engaged in advanced magical work and the philosophical tenets of Setianism. The detailed expositions of 'Remanifestation' and 'aUI' are aimed at practitioners seeking to deepen their understanding and application of Setian principles. Additionally, scholars and serious researchers of modern Western Esotericism, particularly those specializing in the Temple of Set or contemporary magical currents, would find this document invaluable for its historical and doctrinal insights.
